summary.seg: The manuscript Cambridge, University Library, Ff.1.17.1, dated 1180-c.1230, here called The Later Cambridge Songs, was for centuries hidden away and unregarded as part of the binding of a much larger manuscript of slightly later date. The thirty-five songs were copied onto parchment of the poorest quality. The four bifolia were already holed, torn, and creased; some of the holes were re-sewn before use. Over the centuries, with the rebinding of the main manuscript, the flyleaves have been further damaged by glue, hot water, and misplaced binding folds. Age and damp have also taken their toll. The resulting object is physically unhandsome, and in some places untranscribable.

Despite such serious blemishes—or, paradoxically, because of them—this manuscript booklet is of quite exceptional interest. It is a rare survivor of a general species of manuscript which must in its time have been numerous—the informal. Unlike the huge majority of surviving manuscripts from this early period, it was evidently not intended to last. It contains nothing other than the songs, which are untitled, unattributed, and unrubricated. So mean an object could not conceivably have been dedicated or presented to anyone; and it would not have deserved a place in any library. An informal music book of this kind is rare indeed, and in early medieval Britain unique.

British provenance has sometimes been questioned. However, the only positive manuscript evidence points to England. It must have been there at the time of binding, probably in the area of Leicester in the East Midlands. A Latin inscription naming 'Frater Roger of Schepiswed' as the donor of the first item of the theological main manuscript (a well-known Summa de vitiis et virtutibus) appears in the musical flyleaves, and, shortened, also in the main manuscript itself. Shepshed is a village just west of Loughborough.

The main manuscript, now Ff.1.17.2, 292 folios, was acquired from the library of Richard Holdsworth, Master of Emmanuel College, in 1664. At that time MS Ff.1.17.1 had been bound with it for about four centuries as guard-leaves. The two manuscripts came together in the later thirteenth century. The four bifolia which the binder took off his scrap pile would by then have outlived their usefulness, and their music could have been outmoded. The miracle is that he used them entire, wrapping them round the 'new' manuscript without mutilation, except for minimal clipping.

The unhandsomeness of the song booklet, it must be stressed, was there from the beginning, not only in the materials chosen but in the style of presentation. All the texts were intended for music; the ten which are not notated have either blank staves or blank spaces of the appropriate size. The songs were assembled, it appears, by a small group of scribes, working often in considerable haste with scant regard for design, execution, or even consistent legibility. They were not amateurs, but fluent trained scribes, accustomed to copying texts and notating complicated music. (The notation is fluid and cursive, transitional between neumatic and square.) However, on this occasion their standards were low, and a great deal of their work is casual and freehand. It seems likely that they were also the performers.

This apparently self-contained song booklet of sixteen pages transmits thirty-five songs on secular and sacred subjects. The texts are entirely in Latin with the exception of nos. 27 and 31, which introduce phrases in Anglo-Norman. Songs 1-22 are monophonic (twelve unique to the MS); songs 23-35 are polyphonic for two voices (nine unique), with the exception of song 28, for three. The forms are varied and include conducti, strophic cantiones, and sequences; refrain-songs are frequent amongst them. The range of general literary themes is wide; and although the collection is emphatically not liturgical in the narrow sense, the great feasts of the Christmas season, from Advent to Candlemas, are much in evidence. The authors, at least of the texts, whose identities can be deduced from concordances, include Walter of Châtillon, Peter of Blois, and Philip the Chancellor.

John Stevens†
from the Introduction to The Later Cambridge Songs: An English song collection of the twelfth century (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005). Reproduced by permission of Oxford University Press.

msItem.title: Gratulemur dies est leticie
msItem.incipit: 1r Gratulemur dies est leticie. Resurexit verus pastor hodie

msItem.title: Eterni patris filius
msItem.incipit: 1r Eterni patri filius nostrum videns interitum

msItem.title: Resonet intonet fidelis concio
msItem.incipit: 1r Resonet intonet fidelis concio mentibus vocibus solenpni gaudio
msItem.note:
Thie piece is widely known and survives in at least four other manuscripts:
Madrid, Biblioteca Nacional, MS 289, fol. 99v
Naples, Biblioteca Nazionale Vittorio Emanuele III, MS VI G 34, fol. 39v
Vatican City, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, MS Barb. lat. 603, fol. 3r-v
Colmar, Bibliothèque de la ville, MS 187, fol. 45v

msItem.title: Sol ex supernis oritur
msItem.incipit: 1v Sol ex supernis oritur cuius ortu mors moritur

msItem.title: Hec est dies salutaris
msItem.incipit: 1v Hec est [dies] salutaris in qua nobis stella maris
msItem.note:
This piece is known from two other manuscripts:
Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, MS clm 14834, fol. 26r
Prague, University Library, MS VIII.G.16, fols 179v-180r

msItem.title: Tronus regis instauratur
msItem.incipit: 1v Tronus regis instauratur hodie puella
msItem.note: The first stanza and refrain only of perhaps a longer song on the Annunciation.

This piece is known from one other manuscript, Berlin, Staatsbibliothek, MS Phillipps 1996, where it has five stanzas and is found among a collection of Latin verses inserted into the works of Bernard of Clairvaux.

msItem.title: Adulari nesciens
msItem.incipit: 2r Adulari nesciens ab amicis deseror
msItem.note:
This piece is known from three other manuscripts:
Florence, Biblioteca Mediceo-Laurenziana, MS Plut. 29, 1, fol. 429v
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Add. A 44 (the Bekynton MS), fol. 63v
Lyon, Bibliothèque municipale, MS 623, fol. 142r

msItem.title: Argumenta faluntur fisice
msItem.incipit: 2r Argumenta faluntur fisice, ruunt leges Aristotilice

msItem.title: Vacillantis trutine libramine
msItem.incipit: 2r Vacillantis trutine libramine mens suspensa fluctuat
msItem.note:
Versions of this song survive in two other manuscripts:
London, British Library, MS Arundel 384, fol. 234r
Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, clm 4660, fol. 80r (Carmina Burana)

msItem.title: Diastematica vocis armonia
msItem.incipit: 2v Diastematica vocis armonia festa pascalia celebrentur

msItem.title: Ecce torpet probitas
msItem.incipit: 2v-3r [E]cce torpet probitas virtus sepelitur
msItem.note: This song is attributed by Karl Strecker to Walter of Châtillon (active 1170-1180) Walter, of Châtillon, active 1170-1180 .

Of the four other sources containing this poem, one is now lost. The others (all without music) are:
Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, MS clm 4660, fol. 43r
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Add. A 44, fol. 65v
St-Omer, Bibliothèque municipale, MS 351, fol. 19v

msItem.title: Partu prodit arida
msItem.incipit: 3r Partu prodit arida hyeme latente que concepit gravida gremio tumente

msItem.title: In hoc ortus occidente
msItem.incipit: 3v In hoc ortus occidente sol emergens de torrente tenebras illuminat
msItem.note:
This piece is also found with the same music in two other manuscripts:
Florence, Biblioteca Mediceo-Laurenziana, MS Plut. 29, 1
Burgos, Monasterio de Santa Maria la Real de Las Huelgas, MS IX, fol. 167r-v and without music in another two:
Darmstadt, Hessische Landes- und Hochschulbibliothek, MS 2777, fol. 3v, attributed to Philip the Chancellor
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS fonds latin 4880, fol. 84r, alongside poems attributed to Walter of Châtillon .

msItem.title: Licet eger cum egrotis
msItem.incipit: 4r [L]icet eger cum egrotis et ignotus cum ignotis
msItem.note: This piece is found in Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, MS 4660, fol. 45r-v and at least eight other manuscripts.

msItem.title: Dissoluta glatie
msItem.incipit: 4r [D]issoluta glatie gelu temperato temporis primicie vere renovato

msItem.title: Mitis furor
msItem.incipit: 4v Mitis furor amor est cuius dulcis dolor est

msItem.title: Magno gaudens gaudio
msItem.incipit: 4v [M]agno gaudens gaudio nostra puericia sallat cum tripudio propter hec natalia
msItem.note: Song for the Feast of the Holy Innocents (28 December).

msItem.title: Virgo mater salvatoris
msItem.incipit: 4v Virgo mater salvatoris legem sequens hodie fert ad templum Dei verbum sub humana specie
msItem.note: Song for the Feast of the Purification (2 February).

msItem.title: Olim sudor Herculis
msItem.incipit: 5r Olim sudor Herculis monstra late conterens pestes orbis auferens claris longe titulis enituit
msItem.note: Attributed elsewhere to Peter of Blois (approximately 1135-approximately 1212) Peter, of Blois, approximately 1135-approximately 1212 .

msItem.title: Salve festa dies
msItem.incipit: 5v [S]alve festa dies danda gaudio adest sancta sancti Thome passio
msItem.note: Song for the feast of St Thomas of Canterbury (29 December).

msItem.title: Rerum Deus conditor
msItem.incipit: 5v Rerum Deus conditor et mundane molis genitus et genitor carne nostre prolis

msItem.title: Pax in terris
msItem.incipit: 5v Pax in terris nuntiatur in excelsis gloria
msItem.note: A Christmas song which has been attributed to Walter of Châtillon (active 1170-1180) Walter, of Châtillon, active 1170-1180 .

This piece is found in two other manuscripts:
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS fonds latin 904 (the Rouen gradual), fol. 12r
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS fonds latin 4880, fol. 84r

msItem.title: Cantu miro summa laude
msItem.incipit: 5v Cantu miro summa laude summo viro vir applaude quem confortat
msItem.note: Song for the feast of St Nicholas (6 December).

This piece is found in two other manuscripts:
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS fonds latin 3719, fols 24-25r
London, British Library, MS Additional 36881, fol. 12v

msItem.title: Regis cuius potentia
msItem.incipit: 6v Regis cuius potentia manet per cuncta secula
msItem.note: Song for the feast of St Stephen (26 December).

msItem.title: Ad honorem salvatoris
msItem.incipit: 6v Ad honorem salvatoris huius festum confessoris recolit ecclesia

msItem.title: Benedicamus domino Spiritus almi gratia
msItem.incipit: 6v Benedicamus domino Spiritus almi gratia renovati spiritus almie illustrator

msItem.title: Exultemus et letemur
msItem.incipit: 7r Exultemus et letemur Nicolaum veneremur
msItem.note: Song for the feast of St Nicholas (6 December), a conductus ad lectionem (piece to accompany a small procession escorting the reader of the lesson to the lectern).

msItem.title: Verbum patris umanatur
msItem.incipit: 7r Verbum patris umanatur, O O, dum puella saluttur, O O, salutata fecundatur viri nescia
msItem.note:
This piece is found in four other manuscripts, two with music:
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS fonds latin 3719, fol. 91r (for 2 voices)
Munich, Universitätsbibliothek, MS 156 (Moosburg gradual), fols 237v-238r (for 1 voice) and two without:
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS fonds latin 4880, fol. 84v
Graz, Universitätsbibliothek, MS 409, fol. 71r

msItem.title: In natali novi regis
msItem.incipit: 7r In natali novi regis quisquis cantas sive legis omni gaude gaudio
msItem.note: Christmas song for two voices, a conductus ad lectionem (piece to accompany a small procession escorting the reader of the lesson to the lectern).

This piece is found in two other manuscripts:
Munich, Universitätsbibliothek, MS 156 (Moosburg gradual), fols 237v-238r (for 1 voice)
Graz, Universitätsbibliothek, MS 409, fol. 72r (without music)

msItem.title: Hoc in solemnio
msItem.incipit: 7r Hoc in solemnio sallat tripudio homo cum homine
msItem.note: A conductus ad lectionem (piece to accompany a small procession escorting the reader of the lesson to the lectern).

msItem.title: Benedicamus Domino: Amborum sacrum spiramen
msItem.incipit: 7v Benedicamus Domino. Amborum sacrum spiramen nexus amorque

msItem.title: Agnus Dei: Qui pius est factus
msItem.incipit: 8r Agnus Dei. Qui pius es factus prothoplasti sanet ut actus

msItem.title: Divino maduit
msItem.incipit: 8r Divino maduit area rore virgula fronduit indita flore

msItem.title: Flos floriger candor mundicie
msItem.incipit: 8v Flos floriger candor mundicie semper clara lux altrix gratie
msItem.note: Song addressed to the Blessed Virgin Mary.

msItem.title: Ad cantus letitie
msItem.incipit: 8v Ad cantum letitie nos invitat hodie spes et amor patrie celestis
msItem.note: Christmas song which also honours St Michael.
There are ten other sources for this song; this is the earliest and others range in date from the thirteenth to the sixteenth century.

foliation.p:
Two sets of modern pencil pagination and one set of foliation.
1. Upper right corner: 2, 1, 5, 6, 7, 8, 4, 3.
2. Lower right corner: 2, 1, 298, 297, 300, 299, 4, 3.
3. Bottom right hand corner: a2, a1, b1, b2

supportDesc.collation: The manuscript consist of a single quire of eight leaves which was originally used as part of the binding of another manuscript (CUL MS Ff.1.17.2). The leaves were disordered with the two outer bifolia forming the front flyleaves and the two inner bifolia forming the back flyleaves of the composite manuscript.

condition.p: The manuscript is in poor general condition: it has stains and water damage (especially on fol. 2), holes, marks of stitching, and creases as a result of the later binding (especially on fol. 5). The top edges of the pages have been trimmed, leading to some loss of text and notation.

layout.p: The layout is irregular and inconsistent with a mixture of text and music staves on each page. Some of the staves are ruled free hand while others are drawn with a rastrum or ruler. There is little attempt at vertical alignment and texts often extend into the margins. The ruling is in red and/or various shades of brown ink.

handDesc.handNote: With regard to the text, Schumann (1943-50) commented that at first glance the manuscript appears to be written in a single hand; he goes on to identify as many as eleven hands at work. Stevens (2005:9-12) suggests that although there are numerous variations in ink, nib sharpness, size of script, and axis, there may be only two main hands with brief intrusions from one or two others.
With regard to the music hands, Stevens (2005:16-19) suggests that this songbook was written by one main 'hand' (A) in varying 'manners', with substantial contributions from two or three other hands.

physDesc.musicNotation: The style of notation is transitional betwqeen neumatic and quadratic. It may be further characterised as 'cursive', 'itrregular', and 'informal'. (Stevens 2005:12).
physDesc.additions: Flyleaf iiir contains a concordance of the foliation and bibliographical entries in two modern hands.

bindingDesc.p: Early 20th century buckram binding by Gray and Son, Cambridge. Previously used as guard leaves around CUL MS Ff.1.17.2.

provenance.p: At the foot of folio 7v is a donation inscription in a fourteenth-century hand refering to the main volume of which this is orginally a flyleaf (Ff.1.17.2): Summa de vitiis et vertutibus abbreviata ex dono fratris Rogeri de Schepiswed. Shepshed is a village west of Loughborough in Leicestershire.
The manuscript was acquired from the library of Richard Holdsworth (1590-1649) Holdsworth, Richard, 1590-1649 , Master of Emmanuel College, Cambridge, in 1664.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description in the edition and facsimile of the manuscript by John Stevens.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions). Contact the Manuscripts Department for further information on the availability of this manuscript
